title: 109_hr1598
content: The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" improves veterans' benefits for former prisoners of war. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code, by repealing the minimum period of internment for presumption of service connection for certain diseases. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code by adding new diseases presumed to be service-connected, including heart disease, stroke, diabetes (type 2), and osteoporosis. It also grants administrative authority for determining service connection for these additional diseases. The "Prisoner of War Benefits Act of 2005" amends section 1112 of title 38, United States Code to grant administrative authority for determining service connection for additional diseases with a positive association to being a prisoner of war. The Secretary can establish a presumption of service connection for diseases linked to being a prisoner of war based on medical evidence. Recommendations from the Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War and other medical information are considered, with emphasis on statistical significance, replicability, and peer review of studies. The Secretary evaluates studies to establish a presumption of service connection for diseases related to being a prisoner of war. Considerations include statistical significance, replicability, and peer review. If credible evidence supports the association between a disease and being a prisoner of war, a presumption of service connection may be warranted. The Secretary evaluates studies to establish a presumption of service connection for diseases related to being a prisoner of war. If warranted, proposed regulations are issued within 60 days; if not warranted, a notice is published in the Federal Register with an explanation. The Secretary evaluates studies to establish a presumption of service connection for diseases related to being a prisoner of war. If warranted, proposed regulations are issued within 60 days; if not warranted, a notice is published in the Federal Register with an explanation. Final regulations must be issued within 90 days of proposed regulations. If a disease is removed from regulations, veterans awarded compensation based on the presumption provided before the removal will continue to receive benefits. The Secretary ensures veterans awarded compensation for diseases related to being a prisoner of war continue to receive benefits even if the disease is removed from regulations. The Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War is consulted in carrying out this process. The Advisory Committee on Former Prisoners of War is consulted in amending regulations related to diseases for veterans awarded compensation. Amendments include ensuring benefits continue even if a disease is no longer specified.
